snippet: The United States said on Thursday that it would provide the nonlethal aid to help Syria’s opposition provide basic services in areas they control.
abstract: Food rations and medical supplies that Sec of State John Kerry says will be provided to Free Syrian Army mark first time that United States has publicly committed itself to sending nonlethal aid to armed factions battling Pres Bashar al-Assad; supplies fall short of weapons and equipment requested by rebels; Kerry defends offering, indicative of caution on part of Obama administration, saying supplies in conjunction with efforts by other countries will make difference in conflict.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Mark Mazzetti from Washington; Anne Barnard and Hwaida Saad from Beirut, Lebanon; and Christine Hauser from New York.

lead_paragraph: The United States said on Thursday that it would provide the nonlethal aid to help Syria’s opposition provide basic services in areas they control.

headline.seo: U.S. Aid to Syria Shows Obama’s Cautious Approach to Crisis
headline.main: U.S. Steps Up Aid to Syrian Opposition, Pledging $60 Million
headline.print_headline: In American Aid to Syria, A Measure of Caution

keywords.value: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
keywords.name: subject
